I have a great deal of respect of Gundlach's view of the fixed income markets. On bps he is brilliant. But I have listened to him about stocks for years - and, respectfully, I dont think he is an expert on the asset class of equities. His analysis and bullet points just

dont seem that insightful. Why ask him about stocks? What is his general level of expertise on equities? Ask him about fixed income and the Fed's bazooka, not about $AMZN. My two bits. @ScottWapnerCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @jimcramer @tomkeene @business

earnings names and releases. Bottom Line As the market advances (and should investor sentiment improve), the upside reward erodes relative to the downside risk. Currently, the S&P, expected to have a multi-month range of 2550-2950, is within three or four percent from the high

end of that trading range. I continue to see a pivot out of growth and into value realmoney.thestreet.com/doug… - that could cushion the S&P from a meaningful hit - but, nevertheless, I wonder whether we should ... Sell in May and Go Away?

It is a consideration for me now (even though I am bullish over the intermediate term) - particularly if we move quickly to the top end of my projected trading range. Food for thought. $AMZN $MSFT $SPY

@realmoney Beware of Month End Asset Allocation Out of Stocks and Into Bonds * My short term optimism is fading for, as the market advances, the upside/downside deteriorates * The advance is narrow, revenue/profit expectations are perhaps too high (and discounted) for the FANG

constituency * The S&P Index is within 3-4% from the upside of my projected S&P trading range (of 2550-2950) * "Sell in May and Go Away?" * I expect a rotation out of growth and into value that could insulate the markets from a large sell off It is not too early to consider

that the outsized move in equities during the month of March (the largest four week gain in years) will likely bring on a big asset allocation move out of stocks by Thursday (month end). The more we stretch early in the week, the larger the selling could be later in the week.

I also don't like the narrowness of the recent advance (dominated by FANG plus Microsoft). Finally, an Amazon sell on the news event, as I suggested earlier realmoney.thestreet.com/doug…, is not out of the question - and the sell on the news could get contagious around other FANG
As I suggested, a reversal of $AMZN remains a growing probability into EPS release. @realmoney Now down on the day and -$40 from day's high.

@realmoney Time for Second Level Thinking on Amazon? I recently sold out my entire AMZN position as the near term reward v risk has deteriorated after the stock's meteoric rise in the last five weeks. First level thinking: Amazon will have a terrific quarter because of the

"stay at home" restrictions around the world. Second level thinking: Amazon's shares have risen by +$820/share (since March 16, 2020) as a result of the "stay at home" edict - the stock price has more or less discounted the likely robust quarter. $AMZN

the wrong house of worship since the mid- March low. But, when you are committed to price as governing your market view, at what point do you submit to price (if that is at the core of your market views)? * Growing more vociferous (and adamant) perhaps, in part, because of a
foul mood stemming from the "stay at home" edict that exists throughout most of the country as well as the "forced" unemployment and other
emotional impact associated with the induced business slowdown * Failing to recognize that markets bridge to the future (and don't pay

attention to the rear view mirror) * Many may be ignoring the abnormalcy of the day and the possibly short lived impact of Covid-19 * Many may be resisting the ramifications of innovation in the scientific and health communities, are ignoring further evidence of the curve's

flattening and, finally, and perhaps most importantly, are rejecting the consequences of the enormous fiscal bazooka * Some might be skeptical of the implicit and the possible infinite capacity of a future Fed "put" From my perch, with so many defensive, on the sidelines and/or
looking for a retest approaching the March lows -- the "pain trade" is higher. @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @carlquintanilla

From my opener on @realmoney The market is on pace for its best month in eight years. Mr. Market continues to trade well - many I speak to are in disbelief. I, for one, am, unfortunately, quite familiar with "going against the grain" and getting the crap kicked out of me when

I am bearish and the market is rising (and vice versa) - it's a terrible feeling. However, this morning I would ask some of those that are today uttering the loudest bearish growls (in the face of a powerful market rally from the March lows) whether they have strayed from their

General James Mattis, General John Kelly, Rex Tillerson, H.R. McMaster, John Bolton, and dozens of others who have forever tarnished their reputations by supporting Trump’s dangerous policies. But the question of “What have you got to lose?” is not just about Trump’s

promotion of an untested cure for coronavirus. Many voters who were fed up with a system they believe forgot about them voted for Trump on the theory that he couldn’t be worse (for them) than the entrenched system of special interest politics. They have been proven wrong. We

have a lot to lose—like the rule of law, the right to free and fair elections, protection from pandemics, and international peace and security. By hijacking the podium at the daily coronavirus briefings, Americans have finally seen the full horror of Donald Trump in real-time and
unedited. The Dems must indeed offer swing voters something to vote for—but we must also be clear in saying that Donald Trump is a clear and present danger to the well-being of our nation.
the use of the drug after a study showed that one of the “primary outcomes” of the drug was “death.” Per CNBC, "The peer-reviewed Journal of the American Medical

Association released a new study Friday that said researchers cut short a study testing chloroquine as a potential treatment for Covid-19 over safety concerns, citing a “primary outcome” of death. Nearly two dozen patients died and some developed irregular heart rates after
taking doses of the drug daily." Trump’s reckless promotion of the drug likely resulted in avoidable deaths of Covid-19 patients, whose doctors prescribed the drugs at an alarming rate.

(“Prescriptions for two antimalarial drugs jumped by 46 times the average when the president promoted them on TV.”) Although Fox News reported on the FDA’s warning, it mentioned only irregular heart rhythms, not the increase in death among patients treated with the drug. Fox News

, “Hydroxychloroquine use should be avoided outside of hospitals, FDA warns.” The debacle over hydroxychloroquine highlights the fact that doing good science is hard and cannot be rushed. It also highlights the fact that some (many?) members of Trump’s base act like

they are in a cult. They suspend all reason and common sense in following plainly ludicrous suggestions. When Trump suggested ingestion of bleach to fight the coronavirus, the world laughed at his moronic proposal. But in the ensuing days, calls to the NY Poison Control Center

for ingestion of household disinfectants doubled. NY Daily News, “A spike in New Yorkers ingesting household cleaners following Trump’s controversial coronavirus comments.” (“An unusually high number of New Yorkers contacted city health authorities over fears that they had

ingested bleach or other household cleaners in the 18 hours that followed President Trump’s bogus claim that injecting such products could cure coronavirus.” It would be easy to attribute Trump’s positions on hydroxychloroquine and ingesting bleach to ignorance. In fact,

Trump’s ‘ignorance’ is part of a conspiratorial worldview of the far-right, a view that is a mixture of anti-science and magical thinking. Just a few days before Trump suggested using bleach as an internal disinfectant, the “archbishop” of “Genesis II” in Florida wrote to Trump

urging him to promote “Magic Mineral Solution”—which, according to the FDA, is a “dangerous bleach which has caused serious and potentially life-threatening side effects.” The Guardian: “Revealed: leader of group peddling bleach as coronavirus 'cure' wrote to Trump this

week.” Trump’s endorsement of bleach as a possible protectant against coronavirus came just a week after the FDA sought to shut down Genesis II’s sales of Magic Mineral Solution. Whether there is a connection is not clear, but the archbishop of Genesis II wrote the following

after Trump mentioned bleach in Thursday’s daily press briefing, “Trump has got the MMS and all the info!!! Things are happening folks! Lord help others to see the Truth!” Trump is a danger to all Americans during the pandemic. Some of his base will follow his

baseless claims, thereby endangering themselves and others. What is perplexing is why reputable health professionals continue to defend Trump. On Sunday, Dr. Deborah Birx told CNN that the press was being too hard on Trump about his disinfectant comments. NYDaily News:

“Dr. Birx defends Trump for suggesting injecting disinfectant to treat coronavirus: ‘It bothers me that this is still in the news'.” Dr. Birx said, “I worry that we don’t get the information to the American people that they need when we continue to bring up something from

Thursday night.” Dr. Birx also appeared on Fox News to say "I think the media is very slicey and dicey with the way they put together sentences in order to create headlines. I think the responsibility that the press has to really ensure that the headlines

reflect the science and data that is in their piece itself." Dear Dr. Birx, the reason Trump’s comment is still in the news is that responsible news outlets are telling Trump followers not to ingest bleach—which they are doing based on the increased call volume to the

NY Poison Control Center. Health professionals have an affirmative duty to say that Trump was wrong rather than blaming the press for covering Trump’s dangerous comments. Dr. Birx has failed to correct Trump on numerous occasions—an unforgivable failure during a time of

national health crisis. Dr. Birx has never answered Trump’s reckless statement, “What have you got to lose?” She should do so now. When I have criticized Dr. Birx in the past, people I know who know Dr. Birx have written to say she is a consummate professional who is trying

to maintain a delicate balance between remaining “on Trump’s good side” while getting accurate information to the public. If that’s her plan, she is failing—especially when she faults the press for highlighting Trump’s gross recklessness. It may be that Dr. Birx is auditioning

to replace Alex Azar, the current Secretary of Health & Human Services. Politico: “White House weighing plan to replace Azar.” (“Among the candidates to take over as HHS secretary is coronavirus coordinator Deborah Birx.”) The devil’s bargain is not worth it, Dr. Birx. Just ask

@realDonaldTrump When Trump first began promoting hydroxychloroquine as an unproven treatment for Covid-19, one argument he used was the rhetorical question, “What do you have to lose?” The answer turns out to be, “Your life.” On Friday, the FDA issued a stark warning to cease
